item.title: Ticket #773 (mod_rewrite rules don't work with https) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The protocol section (http:) isn't used, but the incorrect RewriteBase rule that is created on https: sites, causes problems.

Under http: we get a RewriteBase that looks like:

RewriteBase /wordpress/

with RewriteRules like:

RewriteRule (page-title)/trackback/?$ /wordpress/index.php?pagename=$1&tb=1 [QSA,L]

But under https: we get:

RewriteBase www.example.ac.uk/wordpress/

The subsequent RewriteRule entries then look like:

RewriteRule (page-title)/trackback/?$ www.example.ac.uk/wordpress/index.php?pagename=$1&tb=1 [QSA,L]

Which results in an http: url rather than https:

I've taken another look at the code, with a fresher eye this time, and can see that the lines:

$site_root = str_replace('​http://', , trim(get_settings('siteurl')));

and

$home_root = str_replace('​http://', , trim(get_settings('home')));

both in function mod_rewrite_rules() in wp-includes/classes.php are the source of this problem. Neither correctly handles an 'https:' in the siteurl or home settings.

Replacing them with:

$site_root = ereg_replace('http(s){0,1}:', , trim(get_settings('siteurl')));

and

$home_root = ereg_replace('http(s){0,1}:', , trim(get_settings('home')));

solves the problem.

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated

item.description: Status changed

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
apache_get_modules() is available only in php 4.3.2 or higher. We must work with 4.1. Also, some hosts don't enable AcceptPathInfo, meaning that the index.php method won't work either. So, we'll probably have to leave permalinks off by default for now.

edited on: 02-14-05 23:05

item.title: Ticket #847 (/archives/%post_id% permalinks break for post ids over 999.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Joen
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #876 (Identify mod_rewrite at install, and if not there, use ...) created
item.dc:creator: Joen
item.description:
Currently, Wordpress has a fairly basic link structure when mod_rewrite is not installed / used.

MediaWiki, on the other hand, has a link structure that is almost similar with and without mod_rewrite. The only difference being "index.php/".

A Wordpress example would be: With rewrite rules: website.com/2005/02/01/postname Without rewrite rules: website.com/index.php/2005/02/01/postname

Ideally, this would be detected when Wordpress is first setup. If mod_rewrite is found, then the nice permalinks are written to the .htaccess. Otherwise, option 2 is used.

Possible? Worthwhile?

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
Agreed; this isn't a problem with the plugins, but rather the sequence in which WordPress prepares post excerpts.

Currently, I'm not even sure if WordPress applies the plugin filters to the excerpts. Here's what the preparation sequence seems to be currently:

  • Strip HTML tags from post
  • Truncate post and append ellipsis

Here's what it *should* be:

  • Apply any post filter plugins (such as Markdown or Textile)
  • Strip HTML tags from post
  • Truncate post and append ellipsis

Without that first step, the underlying syntax of the post will be exposed.

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: Michel Fortin
item.description:
It's not that simple. Markdown does not filter the excerpt currently because it can't do so reliably. The problem is that tags are filtered by WordPress *before* going to Markdown, removing any part of the syntax that looks like a tag. For example, if I write this:

An autolink: <​http://somewhere.com>

A code span: <code>.

The auto link will be removed before Markdown has a chance to see it, and the same applies to the tag inside the code span. (The code tag here would be entity-encoded by Markdown, so it's not really a tag in the final output.)

WordPress should strip tags *after* the excerpt has been filtered. The current tag filter is hard-coded, so it cannot be removed or be put after Markdown.

edited on: 02-14-05 12:04

item.title: Ticket #873 ((patch included) Add user-agent field to trackbacks) updated
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #873 ((patch included) Add user-agent field to trackbacks) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: This patch (made against 1.5 but should apply to 1.2 with some fuzz/offset) adds a User-Agent: field to outgoing trackbacks. Some users use User-Agent field to determine if the client making the connection is valid, and will treat blank user agents more harshly. This lets people identify incoming trackbacks as WordPress software.

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: dnorman
item.description:
Looks like it's having issues on the call to wp_update_post() on line 616 of xmlrpc.php - that's the error message I'm getting, anyway... "Sorry, your entry could not be edited. Something wrong happened."

Also, I just noticed that the last parameter in the edit xmlrpc call has the publish parameter set to <boolean>0</boolean> - would this kick a post into draft?

item.title: Ticket #867 (single_month_title() broken for single-digit months) created
item.dc:creator: dimock
item.description: Single_month_title() does not append a leadning zero to single-digit months when looking up the name from the $month array, which expects a leading zero. The result is null output when calling single_month_title() for months 1-9. See below for proposed fix.

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: dnorman
item.description: I just tried in Ecto in order to see if it is a bug in MarsEdit, and Ecto gets the same generic error message, with the edited post being bumped into Draft mode.

item.title: Ticket #866 (author funcs should be parallel with cat funcs) created
item.dc:creator: dmclark
item.description: In terms of consistency in the api, I have always found it oddd and frustrating that the author functions are all based on $post, rather than accepting an $author_id like category functions

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: dnorman
item.description:
I've just confirmed that this bug is still present in WP 1.5 Gamma 2005-02-13. After editing a post, I had to use the WP-Admin interface to manage the post, and manually publish it again. MarsEdit 1.0 with WP 1.5 Gamma 2005-02-13.

I posted about it on my weblog at ​http://www.darcynorman.net/2005/02/06/trying-out-marsedit-again and Brent Simmons, the developer of MarsEdit, confirmed that he's seen the bug as well (and I've also filed it as a bug in MarsEdit just in case)

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description: Sorry, forgot to mention: The Version I recognized this problem in was the wordpress-2005-02-13 nightly build.

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #865 (Wrong arguments for user_can_edit_user() in wp-admin/edit.php) created
item.dc:creator: Agent Orange
item.description:
When the list of posts is displayed, there are lines like this:

case 'control_delete':

?> <td><?php if ( user_can_edit_user($user_level,$authordata->user_level) ) { echo "<a href='post.php?action=delete&post=$id' class='delete' onclick=\"return confirm('" . sprintf(("You are about to delete this post \'%s\'
n \'OK\' to delete, \'Cancel\' to stop."), wp_specialchars(get_the_title(, ), 1) ) . "')\">" . ('Delete') . "</a>"; } ?></td> <?php break;

The arguments for user_can_edit_user() are completely wrong here. The correct line would look like:

case 'control_edit':

?> <td><?php if ( user_can_edit_user($user_ID,$authordata->ID) ) { echo "<a href='post.php?action=edit&post=$id' class='edit'>" . ('Edit') . "</a>"; } ?></td> <?php break;

So, you have to submit the user id's to the function user_can_edit_user, not the levels.

item.title: Ticket #855 (No email notification for comments) updated
item.dc:creator: Lucky
item.description:
I have the same problem found in the nightly built 12.02.05 and 13.02.05 My E-Mail is the same before that bug appear.

No notification when a comment is in the moderation list and no notification when a comment arrived.

I can't say when it starts because before I used 12.02.05 I have used a nightly built from the end of january.

item.title: Ticket #864 (Only 1 single entry showing in feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: Morgaine
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #864 (Only 1 single entry showing in feeds) created
item.dc:creator: Morgaine
item.description:
When using 1.5-gamma 2005-02-12, with 'Blog pages, Show at most' set to 1 post in the admin interface, Options - Reading, and 'Syndication feeds, Show the most recent 10 posts, For each article, show Full text', there is only 1 post in the feed as well. Changing 'Blog pages, Show at most' to e.g. 10, makes the feeds behave as expected. When changing it back to 1, the feeds contain only 1 entry, even though it's set to contain 10 posts.

In 1.5-beta-1 2005-01-28 the problem didn't occur.

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
20:

​http://wordpress.org/pipermail/cvs/2005-February/001123.html

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Sample plugin attached.

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Here's the list of filters:

theme_root - The base theme directory. Default: ABSPATH/wp-content/themes

theme_root_uri - The base theme uri. Default: siteurl/wp-content/themes

stylesheet_directory - The directory containing the active stylesheet. Default: theme_root/stylesheet-theme-name

stylesheet_directory_uri - The uri of the directory containing the active stylesheet. Default: theme_root_uri/stylesheet-theme-name

stylesheet_uri - The uri of the active stylesheet. Default: stylesheet_directory_uri/style.css

template_directory - The directory containing the active template. Default: theme_root/template-theme-name

template_directory_uri - The uri of the directory containing the active template. Default: theme_root_uri/template-theme-name

To relocate from wp-contet/themes/ to /themes/, hook into the theme_root and theme_root_uri filters. Changes made to those will be picked up by the stylesheets and templates.

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #863 (Allow theme location to be changed through filters.) created
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Add filters so that the theme root, template directory, stylesheet directory, and associated URIs can be changed via plugins.
